content.description: Wounded Right There has big moves to big holds. Some look suspect, but everything felt solid. It felt easier than 10c.
content.location: It is the 4th route from right.

content.description:
This route is better than it looks from the ground, as long as you don't mind a touch of choss.  The rock is more solid than it appears, but the rating of 5.9 is a bit inflated.  It felt more like a low 5.8 or maybe even a high 5.7 to most in our party.  Then again, we started via the ramp to the left, which certainly makes it easier than trying to do the direct start.

For more information, check out "Arkansas Valley Climbing" by Tom Perkins.
content.protection: Draws 6-ish, not including anchors.  There are chains at the top.
content.location:
This is the second route in from the far right-hand side of the crag. It [does not] share a set of anchors with

Warrior's Cry

, which is to its right.

Per

Nicholas Webb

: it has its own anchors.

content.description: Surprisingly fun, this route appears to climb ledge to ledge, but there is only one honest-to-goodness no-hands rest.  The crux is near the top (more enduro than power) and is made easier if you're comfortable with hand jams (there's only one).  It might be a bit soft for the grade, but regardless of the rating, it's a heck of a lot of fun, especially down low.
content.protection: 8-ish draws not including anchors, coldshuts at the top. Personally, I would bring one long (shoulder length) draw.  About halfway up, there's a bolt that loads a biner on a standard length draw directly over an edge.  It's not at the crux, but you could easily fall clipping the next bolt, and there's a ledge below.
content.location:
About the middle of the wall, climb the obvious light streak just to the left of the obvious black streak.

For more information, check out "

Arkansas Valley Climbing

" by Tom Perkins.

content.description: A slippery start leads to great holds just above. Pass left of the roof, traverse back right, and head straight up for the anchors.
content.location: Warrior's Cry is the rightmost bolted route on the wall.

content.description:
I would have given 1 star if it had an anchor, but the traverse is sketch! It didn't look like topping out was a good option either.

Per

nate post

: there is an anchor, you have to top out, and it's easier to climb the run out to the top than traverse to the anchors on

Warrior's Tears

. I climbed it today, I topped out, and there are two steel cables with a steel ring. This is probably not very good for setting up a TR but good for rapping off the route.
content.protection:
It has a mix of homemade hangers, a couple of new bolts, and an old piton. There are 7 clips in all.

There is no anchor!

Traverse to the top of

Warrior's Tears

.
content.location: This is the 3rd route from the left.
This is left of Warrior's Wall.

content.description: This route starts off easy enough, but then it punches you in the face, so be ready. The last two or three moves to the anchors are stout, at least for me at 5.9. I really had to go for it. Either way, it's a fun climb with a killer last move to the anchors. I imagine it would be quite a bit easier if you have two inches more reach than I do.
content.location:
It is just right of

Warrior's Tears

.

content.description:
Even though the rating in Tom Perkins' guidebook is 5.8, I would personally call this route 5.9+.  It has one distinct balancy crux that easily makes it more difficult than

Warrior's Wail

(the "5.9" just down the wall).  Overall, it is a good route with fun moves.
content.protection: 7-ish bolts with coldshuts at the top.
content.location: This is the leftmost bolted route on the wall.
